div.p: I wrote a letter to you at the end of February; I hope it has been delivered. On May 11th, I received letters from Bullinger and Lavater, and yours, Gwalther, on the 18th of the same month. The Queen of Scots escaped from prison around the same time. A bloody battle was suddenly fought between the papists, friends of the queen, and the protestants, supporters of the king. She, while the battle was raging, was observing everything from a hill on a swift horse; but when she finally saw that victory had gone to Lord James and his men, she fled with a few to England; for she preferred to entrust herself to the English rather than her own Scots, and I believe it was safer. She is now at Carlisle, in a fairly fortified place, and will soon reside in the middle of England, as I hear. On July 13th, Lord William Turner, a good doctor and an excellent man, died in London; Lever preached at his funeral. I have written this single letter to you and indeed briefly; for I doubt whether these, in such great tumults of affairs, will reach your hands, therefore I did not want to write more at present.
Greet in my name all my friends and especially Lord Simler, Lavater, Wolff, Haller, Wick, Vonlich, Zwingli, etc. Farewell well.
Yours as much as he is, John Parkhurst, Bishop of Norwich.
To the most learned men and most upright friends, Lord Rudolf Gwalther and Lord Heinrich Bullinger.
